Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Improving Accuracy and Reducing Scan Time of Dynamic Brain PET
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I Project will productize a quantitative data processing technology in dynamic positron emission tomography (PET). Dynamic PET's distinction from its static counterpart is in the fact that it collects time-dependent tracer concentration data. It is a highly sensitive and accurate way of functional and molecular imaging of protein targets such as biomarkers of Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, or brain trauma. Unfortunately, dynamic PET is rarely used in clinic because of long imaging time and complex processing. The technology to be developed in this proposal will shorten the required imaging time and simplify the analysis, allowing for accurate and reliable imaging of disease biomarkers for aiding drug development, clinical diagnostics, and treatment monitoring. The proposed analytic workflow will be offered as a cloud-based service that can be used by the customers to analyze new or historical PET datasets. In order to overcome the established practice of relying on less accurate and informative static PET imaging, the grant recipients plan to conduct a thorough validation of the new technology using a dedicated physical phantom and human subject images acquired in the past. The largest impact of the new technology is expected in medical research and drug development.

The accepted practice of analyzing dynamic PET datasets involves reconstruction of the parameters of implied compartment model describing the tracer biochemistry, which involves several accuracy-degrading approximations and requires lengthy acquisition. The alternative approach proposed in this project relies on decomposing the dynamic PET image sequences using a combination of several processing techniques that incorporate the essential features of tracer pharmacokinetics without making explicit assumptions about the model parameters or about the underlying anatomy. The key part of the proposed methodology is factor analysis of dynamic structures, a non-negative matrix decomposition technique with successful past applications in radionuclide image analysis. The result of the workflow is a 3D concentration of tissues that exhibit specific-binding of the radiotracer. In order to validate the quantitative accuracy of the approach, the researchers will build and image a dedicated physical phantom capable of producing overlapping distributions with different tracer dynamics. In order to validate the scan-time reduction claims, the new workflow will be used to analyze existing dynamic PET human subject datasets using increasingly shorter input time windows.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the Phase I portion of this SBIR project consisted of three components:

1)     software development, testing, and cloud deployment of Intelligent Dynamics-Driven Quantitative Diagnostics  (IDDQD) code version 1.0;

2)     construction and experiments with physical dynamic phantom for method validation;

3)     and processing of human subject PET data for proof-of-concept and confirmation of acquisition time reduction.

         The team has made significant progress in all these tasks, achieving and exceeding minimum viable completion levels for all three milestone goals.

Principal software development. Version 1.0 of the code has been completed. Intelligent Dynamics-Driven Quantitative Diagnostics software code IDDQD.1.0 has been implemented in Python 2.7, validated, and tested on Linux, MacOS, and Windows platforms. The code was deployed in the virtual machine environment using cloud-computing platform Linode. At this stage, the code exists as a collection of Python functions implementing the principal stages of the workflow: data preparation and filtering, representative clustering (R-clustering), factor analysis of dynamic structures (FADS), and GUI-assisted data cleaning. These functions that can be imported and executed from external Python scripts or run sequentially using an umbrella bash script (bash is a popular shell environment available for all major Unix and Unix descendant operating systems). We also identified the major directions of work for developing the 2.0 version of the code to be proposed in Phase II, such as adding various new regularization constraints and implementing back-end integration of the code with a web-portal.

Dynamic physical phantom (DBP) research. Due to scheduling conflicts with the subcontract institution, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL), the work on phantom construction and experiments underwent some minor setbacks: the originally proposed version of the phantom had design or implementation flaws that made it difficult to use with the injection of radioactivity. Our team eventually found an innovative solution to the problem and built a simpler version of the DBR, which was subsequently imaged at LBNL’s PET facility. The acquired images (250 timeframes for each of the three overlapping compartments) were compiled into a database that could be used to generate a PET dataset simulating a true dynamic distribution with prescribed input function and tracer kinetics. We generated ten such datasets for ten different dynamic scenarios and reconstructed them using IDDQD.1.0. For each scenario, we created 32 statistically independent instances of a dynamic dataset by arbitrarily selected subsets from the master database, which allowed us to evaluate the quality of the reconstruction in statistically significant way. The results of the simulated experiments demonstrated general feasibility and stability of the method. The algorithm was able to differentiate even significantly similar tissue curves. For the kinds of tracer dynamics normally encountered in brain PET, the algorithm was able to obtain the distribution of specific-binding tissue with 96-98% accuracy. The phantom was characterized using voxel intensity correlation as the principal similarity measure. Additional research on the available data will be required to compute absolute tracer quantitation from the dynamic images.

Human subject brain PET analysis research. SolvingDynamics originally planned to obtain 30 human subject dynamic PET datasets acquired by our collaborators in the course of their earlier research. We were aiming to obtain 10 datasets for each of three different radionuclide tracers: 11C-PIB (beta-amyloid biomarker), 11C-raclopride (beta-dopamine re-uptake receptor biomarker), and 18F-AV1451 (tau protein biomarker). At this time, we received data for two of the three tracers, PIB and AV1451, but have not been able to obtain all of the regulatory permissions to access the raclopride data. Our team continues to negotiate with LBNL and their partner institutions, trying to gain access to more dynamic datasets from these and other radiotracers. While pursuing access to this additional data, our team reconstructed ten PIB and ten AV1451 datasets, validating IDDQD’s applicability to image two key dementia biomarkers. We were successful in reconstructing the target biomarker distributions from both the full available dataset (90 or 100 minutes long) and from as little as the first 30 minutes of the scan. When using more than three factors (FADS) for the AV1451 data, we saw indications that IDDQD can distinguish between two different specific-binding tissues, only one of which being associated with tau, the intended physiological target of the imaging, potentially suggesting that the currently used reference region methods produce biased results, which can be improved only using IDDQD or other FADS methods.

Overall, our Phase I program was successful: achieving our principal goals of proving feasibility of IDDQD and demonstrating its advantages over alternative approaches to PET-based diagnostics.


Last Modified: 11/27/2019
Modified by: Grant T Gullberg
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goals of the Phase I portion of this SBIR project consisted of three components: 1) software development, testing, and cloud deployment of Intelligent Dynamics-Driven Quantitative Diagnostics (IDDQD) code version 1.0; 2) construction and experiments with physical dynamic phantom for method validation; 3) and processing of human subject PET data for proof-of-concept and confirmation of acquisition time reduction. The team has made significant progress in all these tasks, achieving and exceeding minimum viable completion levels for all three milestone goals. Principal software development. Version 1.0 of the code has been completed. Intelligent Dynamics-Driven Quantitative Diagnostics software code IDDQD.1.0 has been implemented in Python 2.7, validated, and tested on Linux, MacOS, and Windows platforms. The code was deployed in the virtual machine environment using cloud-computing platform Linode. At this stage, the code exists as a collection of Python functions implementing the principal stages of the workflow: data preparation and filtering, representative clustering (R-clustering), factor analysis of dynamic structures (FADS), and GUI-assisted data cleaning. These functions that can be imported and executed from external Python scripts or run sequentially using an umbrella bash script (bash is a popular shell environment available for all major Unix and Unix descendant operating systems). We also identified the major directions of work for developing the 2.0 version of the code to be proposed in Phase II, such as adding various new regularization constraints and implementing back-end integration of the code with a web-portal. Our team eventually found an innovative solution to the problem and built a simpler version of the DBR, which was subsequently imaged at LBNL’s PET facility. The acquired images (250 timeframes for each of the three overlapping compartments) were compiled into a database that could be used to generate a PET dataset simulating a true dynamic distribution with prescribed input function and tracer kinetics. We generated ten such datasets for ten different dynamic scenarios and reconstructed them using IDDQD.1.0. The results of the simulated experiments demonstrated general feasibility and stability of the method. The algorithm was able to differentiate even significantly similar tissue curves. The phantom was characterized using voxel intensity correlation as the principal similarity measure. SolvingDynamics originally planned to obtain 30 human subject dynamic PET datasets acquired by our collaborators in the course of their earlier research. We were aiming to obtain 10 datasets for each of three different radionuclide tracers: 11C-PIB (beta-amyloid biomarker), 11C-raclopride (beta-dopamine re-uptake receptor biomarker), and 18F-AV1451 (tau protein biomarker). At this time, we received data for two of the three tracers, PIB and AV1451, but have not been able to obtain all of the regulatory permissions to access the raclopride data. While pursuing access to this additional data, our team reconstructed ten PIB and ten AV1451 datasets, validating IDDQD’s applicability to image two key dementia biomarkers. We were successful in reconstructing the target biomarker distributions from both the full available dataset (90 or 100 minutes long) and from as little as the first 30 minutes of the scan. When using more than three factors (FADS) for the AV1451 data, we saw indications that IDDQD can distinguish between two different specific-binding tissues, only one of which being associated with tau, the intended physiological target of the imaging, potentially suggesting that the currently used reference region methods produce biased results, which can be improved only using IDDQD or other FADS methods. Overall, our Phase I program was successful: achieving our principal goals of proving feasibility of IDDQD and demonstrating its advantages over alternative approaches to PET-based diagnostics.
